018package org.tquadrat.foundation.lang.internal;
019
020import static org.apiguardian.api.API.Status.INTERNAL;
021
022import java.util.Formatter;
023import java.util.IllegalFormatException;
024import java.util.Locale;
025import java.util.function.Supplier;
026
027import org.apiguardian.api.API;
028import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.ClassVersion;
029import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.UtilityClass;
030import org.tquadrat.foundation.exception.PrivateConstructorForStaticClassCalledError;
031
032/**
033 *  This class provides an implementation of
034 *  {@link java.lang.String#format(Locale,String,Object...) String.format()}
035 *  that uses a shared instance of
036 *  {@link java.util.Formatter}.
037 *
038 *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
039 *  @version $Id: SharedFormatter.java 820 2020-12-29 20:34:22Z tquadrat $
040 *  @since 0.1.0
041 *
042 *  @UMLGraph.link
043 */
044@ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: SharedFormatter.java 820 2020-12-29 20:34:22Z tquadrat $" )
045@API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
046@UtilityClass
047public final class SharedFormatter
048{
049        /*-----------*\
050    ====** Constants **========================================================
051        \*-----------*/
052    /**
053     *  The initial buffer size that is used by
054     *  {@link #format(String, Object...)}
055     *  and
056     *  {@link #format(Locale, String, Object...)}
057     *  (per thread): {@value}.
058     *
059     *  @since 0.1.0
060     */
061    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
062    public static final int FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE = 2048;
063
064        /*------------------------*\
065    ====** Static Initialisations **===========================================
066        \*------------------------*/
067    /**
068     *  The cached
069     *  {@link Formatter}
070     *  instance.
071     */
072    private static final ThreadLocal<Formatter> m_Formatter;
073
074    static
075    {
076        //---* The cached Formatter instance *---------------------------------
077        final Supplier<Formatter> initializer = () -> new Formatter( new StringBuilder( FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE ), Locale.getDefault( Locale.Category.FORMAT ) );
078        //noinspection RedundantTypeArguments
079        m_Formatter = ThreadLocal.<Formatter>withInitial( initializer );
080    }
081
082        /*--------------*\
083    ====** Constructors **=====================================================
084        \*--------------*/
085    /**
086     *  No instance of this class is allowed.
087     */
088    private SharedFormatter() { throw new PrivateConstructorForStaticClassCalledError( SharedFormatter.class ); }
089
090        /*---------*\
091    ====** Methods **==========================================================
092        \*---------*/
093    /**
094     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified format String and
095     *  arguments.<br>
096     *  <br>The implementation uses internally the
097     *  {@link Locale}
098     *  that is returned by
099     *  {@link java.util.Locale#getDefault() Locale.getDefault()}.<br>
100     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
101     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
102     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
103     *  {@link Formatter}
104     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
105     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
106     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
107     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
108     *  <br>This implementation is about as twice as fast as
109     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
110     *
111     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
112     *      {@link Formatter}
113     *      class.
114     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
115     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
116     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
117     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
118     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
119     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
120     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
121     *      depends on the conversion.
122     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
123     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
124     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
125     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
126     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
127     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
128     *  @return A formatted String.
129     *
130     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
131     *
132     *  @since 0.1.0
133     */
134    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
135    public static final String format( final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
136    {
137        return format( Locale.getDefault( Locale.Category.FORMAT ), format, args );
138    }   //  format()
139
140    /**
141     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified
142     *  {@link Locale},
143     *  format String, and arguments.<br>
144     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
145     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
146     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
147     *  {@link Formatter}
148     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
149     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
150     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
151     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
152     *  <br>The performance gain for this implementation is not that impressive
153     *  when compared with that of
154     *  {@link #format(String, Object...)},
155     *  but still in the 10% range.
156     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
157     *
158     *  @param  locale  The
159     *      {@link Locale}
160     *      that will be applied during formatting. If {@code locale} is
161     *      {@code null} then no localisation is applied.
162     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
163     *      {@link Formatter}
164     *      class.
165     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
166     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
167     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
168     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
169     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
170     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
171     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
172     *      depends on the conversion.
173     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
174     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
175     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
176     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
177     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
178     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
179     *  @return A formatted String.
180     *
181     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
182     *
183     *  @since 0.1.0
184     */
185    @SuppressWarnings( "resource" )
186    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
187    public static final String format( final Locale locale, final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
188    {
189        /*
190         * When this method StringUtils.format() is used inside an
191         * implementation of Formattable.formatTo() that in turn was called by
192         * this method already, the internal out buffer of the formatter
193         * contains already some text that has to be preserved.
194         *
195         * Therefore, the current length of the out buffer is kept before new
196         * contents is added by the call to formatter.format(), and reset after
197         * the new formatted text was retrieved from that buffer.
198         */
199        final var formatter = m_Formatter.get();
200        final var result = (StringBuilder) formatter.out();
201        final var currentPos = result.length();
202        formatter.format( locale, format, args );
203        final var retValue = result.substring( currentPos );
204
205        if( (currentPos == 0) && (result.capacity() > FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE) )
206        {
207            /*
208             * The intention of this code is to reduce the memory  footprint of
209             * the formatter that is mainly determined by the StringBuilder
210             * that is used for the output.
211             */
212            result.setLength( FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE );
213            result.trimToSize();
214        }
215        result.setLength( currentPos );
216
217        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
218        return retValue;
219    }   //  format()
220}
221//  class SharedFormatter
222
223/*
224 *    End of File
225 */
